**The elegant solution:** Picture the graph of the cosine function above that has a minimum value at $x=\pi$ and a horizontal tangent at that point must have a slope of $0$. If you recognize that the limit expression equals the slope along $g$ at $x=\pi$, then the problem is trivial. Since there is a horizontal tangent at $x=\pi$, then the slope at $x=\pi$ must be $0$.

**An alternate solution:** We have no way of evaluating this limit expression using an algebraic approach at this point. So we can resort to numerical techniques by evaluating the limit expression

$\qquad \displaystyle \lim_{h\to 0}\dfrac{\cos(\pi+h)-g(\pi)}{h}$

for $h=-0.001$ and $h=0.001$.

$\qquad \displaystyle \lim_{h\to 0}\dfrac{\cos(\pi-0.001)-g(\pi)}{-0.001}=-0.0005$.

$\qquad \displaystyle \lim_{h\to 0}\dfrac{\cos(\pi+0.001)-g(\pi)}{0.001}=0.0005$.

This gives good evidence to explain why $0$ is an excellent guess for the value of the limit expression.

question.content:
